Award.AwardTitle: Terahertz source frequency comb based on difference frequency generation from a mid-IR quantum cascade laser

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Compact, Chip-based Terahertz Frequency Comb

Abstract

Non-techniical: A frequency comb is a light source whose spectrum consists of a series of discrete, equally spaced elements. Since their discovery in the 1990s, frequency combs have revolutionized metrology, spectroscopy, and frequency synthesis with extraordinary precision and speed. However, spectroscopic applications are limited by the wavelength range that is accessible by the comb. The terahertz (THz) spectral range, where abundant molecules have strong spectral fingerprints or feature broad absorption bands, is not easily accessible with current comb technology. The main challenge is the need for multiple optical components or cryogenic cooling, which leads to a complicated and expensive source. A novel approach is proposed to develop a chip-based THz frequency comb source operating at room temperature. This simple to use and compact source will be an enabling technology which will allow easy access to THz spectroscopy/ imaging for the broader scientific community.

Technical: The objective of the proposed research is to demonstrate a room temperature, continuous wave, monolithic THz frequency comb source with sub-milliwatt level output power. The approach is to use a mid-IR quantum cascade laser (QCL) engineered with a flat-top gain and large 2nd and 3rd order optical nonlinearities for the intracavity difference frequency generation (DFG) of a THz frequency comb. A dual-section cavity design is proposed to render the mid-infrared pump source with an output exhibiting a unique combination of single- and multi-mode operation. The multi-mode output can be locked to equally spaced comb modes via four wave mixing and an engineered near-zero group velocity dispersion. Such a cavity scheme provides the perfect conditions for creating a THz comb output via the DFG process and a broadband Ãˆerenkov phase matching scheme. In contrast to a mode-locked laser comb source, which is bulky and expensive, the proposed THz comb source offers a monolithic solution that, once developed, has potential for cost-effective mass production using the existing semiconductor laser fabrication infrastructure. This project is an excellent example of a multidisciplinary approach used to circumvent existing technological limitations. Solid state physics, material science, nonlinear optics, and laser physics are all major components of the research plan, which are all supported generally by NSF, and are used, in this case, together to combine multiple functional elements into a single, compact, high power device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project ‘Terahertz source frequency comb based on difference frequency generation from a mid-IR quantum cascade laser’ (Federal Award ID: 1505409) addresses critical needs in the field of high-power continuous wave (CW), broadband mid-IR to THz laser comb source at room temperature. This type of chip-based comb source has numerous applications in basic sciences, as well as in spectroscopy, metrology, ranging and detection, astronomy, and environmental monitoring. With the support of this project, we create a revolutionary continuous wave monolithic laser comb source working at room temperature which is mass-producible and has Watt power output at room temperature continuous wave operation with a broad frequency coverage over 3 THz range.

The core achievements of this project are: (1) Demonstrated world's the most efficient semiconductor frequency comb sources (6.5% at 293 K) based on quantum cascade lasers (QCLs) at 37.5 THz. (This work was published in Nature Scientific Reports: 7,43806 (2017)). (2) Demonstrated the high power dispersion compensated laser frequency comb using Gires–Tournois Interferometer (GTI) mirror technique. Room temperature THz emitter is active area of investigation in the optoelectronic and physics communities. (3) Demonstrated the highest power output (~1 W) at 56.6 THz at room temperature continuous operation. The accomplished results of this project aroused lots of interest to many people in these fields and received extensive scientific media reports, such as Northwestern McCormick News, phys.org, etc. In addition, the demonstrated dual comb heterodyne spectroscopy technique will be of interest to a much wider community of scientists, for a variety of spectroscopy, metrology, imaging, and medical applications.

With this research, we systematically address many basic problems existing for previous QCL comb sources by using an optimized active region design with balanced gain profile, a low-loss GTI mirror based on Y2O3/TiO2, and improved packaging technique based on patterned submounts. The demonstrated comb device has a truly small size of 10*10*2 mm3 after packaging on submounts, operates at room temperature continuous wave operation with a broadband spectrum covering 3 THz (100 cm-1). As such, demonstrated dual comb heterodyne spectroscopy can be a drop-in replacement for existing light sources in many spectroscopy applications. Also, with significant potential for mass production, the source can be made cheaply, similar to other semiconductor lasers. This will allow many more people access to optical frequency comb sources for novel and unique research.

This NSF project also makes an excellent case study for how theory, technology, and experiment all play a role in developing a high power frequency comb laser source. As such, aspects of the device design and fabrication have been incorporated into the Solid State Engineering curriculum at Northwestern University as real-world examples. Graduate students and post-docs funded through this work were able to present this work to course attendees and at conferences. The involvement of undergraduates and high-school students (through mentorship) has been emphasized, by leveraging existing programs with a strong focus on under-represented minorities, to increase the effectiveness and scope of the program.
